user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_QueueGetInfo(osal_id_t queue_id, OS_queue_prop_t *queue_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_prop);

    memset(queue_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_queue_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_queue_table, token);

        strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1);
        queue_prop->creator = record->creator;

        /*
         * Currently there are no additional queue details provided by the impl layer -
         * But this could be added in the future (i.e. current/max depth, msg size, etc)
         */

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_queue_table
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_queue_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 concerns the correctness of for statements (their three clauses, single loop counter, no modifications of the counter in the body, etc.). In the provided target function OS_QueueGetInfo and the supplied related definitions there are no for statements to inspect:

- OS_QueueGetInfo contains calls (OS_CHECK_POINTER, memset, OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, strncpy, OS_ObjectIdRelease) and simple assignments/ifs, but no for loops.
- The macros/inline used here are simple (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to an array indexing expression, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken returns token->obj_idx) and contain no for loops.
- The provided implementation of OS_ObjectIdGetById contains conditional logic but no for loops. OS_ObjectIdRelease is a simple wrapper.

Therefore there are no for-loop occurrences in the provided code fragments that would trigger investigation under Rule 14.2. Note: the only remaining potential places where for loops could exist are the implementations of external/standard routines not provided here (e.g. memset/strncpy or other OS_ObjectIdTransaction* helpers). If those implementations are part of the checked codebase, their definitions should be inspected for for-statements that might violate Rule 14.2. Since those implementations were not supplied, they cannot be marked here as suspicious fragments.
